description.text: replacement knob

3D printable VHF/UHF antenna for HDTV. measure 7x7 inches.  
Minor update to the one I made.
Materials needed

1 sheet of aluminum foil
4 3mm x 4 inches steel, copper, tin etc. rode.
2, wires (I cut my from discarded network cabled)
1, Balun - UHF/VHF/FM
1, copper tape or aluminum tape.
1, crazy glue or hot glue gun.
Some solder paste Tool,

Screw driver
Solder iron. 1) Fold the aluminum foil sheet neatly into the back of the UHF, don't install the brace just yet. 2) Insert 4 copper rods into each hole on the VHF stand. 3) strip 1 of your wires about 4 inches naked and solder straight down to each exposed rod in the center. Strip the other end of the wire about 3mm. 4) Strip 1 wire about 3mm on one side and about 1 inch on the other end. Make a flat loop on the 1 inch tripped side and tape it to the back of the aluminum foil. (good luck if you like to solder it) Install the back brace to keep the foil in place. 5) Insert the Balun into the back hole and glue it tight. Now insert your UHF/VHF into the each hole at the top and glue them down. Screw them down if you like. Solder each end of the wire to each leg of the Balun. Use you hot glue or electric tap to cover each solder so they can't touch. Cover the bottom with the base cover. You antenna is now completed. Disclaimer,
This is purely for hobby and educational purposes. I am not solely responsible for any of your action or injury during or after the making of this project.

title: Optical positioning reference
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This object was designed such that a single image of it contains the information necessary to calculate the relative location of the camera used to capture the image. It is intended to be printed using a standard colour printer, and then folded into shape and affixed to e.g. a wall etc. This design was inspired by the potential of remote-controlled, camera-equipped vehicles such as the Parrot AR drone (http://www.parrot.com/). While these systems can theoretically be fully computer controlled using dead-reckoning to navigate (IIRC the Parrot has available Linux drivers), inevitable errors in positioning will accumulate, preventing the drone from making long distance runs, returning to a charging station, etc. The idea here is to permit the drone to navigate autonomously and periodically correct its position by capturing images of strategically located reference markers. The black and white border (A) provides a high contrast identifier and sets the reference frame, while the red, green and blue corners break rotational and reflective (in case your drone sees one in a mirror) symmetry. The angled blue / yellow panels in B permit distinguishing between the angled view from one side vs the other (or a bit above vs a bit below), and the raised central area C contains whatever data you wish to put on it. This version contains a QR code linking back to this site, however you could substitute simple identifier codes to distinguish reference markers at different locations, or any other data you want. Possible applications include anything from autonomous orienteering challenges (each marker displays the instructions to find the next marker) to home security systems (for example a drone patrolling your hackerspace at night, updating its location by capturing images of unique positioning references in each room, and returning to a 3D printed dock/charging station as needed to top up its batteries).

Cut out shape, fold according to attached folding guide image - with the printed side facing you, fold panels B away from you, and panels C towards you (although I find it easier to fold them away initially to get the alignment right, and then reverse the crease). The grey tabs go under the adjacent panels - they should not be visible from the front when you are done - and are taped or glued in place. And you're done. NB the information you can put in the central area A is only limited by the resolution of the camera it will be used with, and the range at which it will be viewed. In the attached SVG file, that area is 5 cm x 5 cm - right now it contains the QR code linking back to this page, but you can substitute whatever you like here (for example if the objective is to uniquely identify one reference point among several, a 5 x 5 pixel array might give you better viewing range).

title: Y Plate for Printrbot Simple Maker Edition

description.text:
This is a remix of iamjonlawrence excellent "1405 300mm No Sag, Printrbot Simple" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:372467 for his Y-Plate only.
I have a 2013 version of PB Simple and my Z-Nut doesn't fit well in jon's version. It's too loose. So i've made a new version of his Y-plate that fits my Z-Nut exactly. I've also made a Z-Nut item for those who broke or damaged their Z-Nut : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:546652
There's 2 versions of the plate :
  • Original (for the original Z-nut)
  • Spaced (for my Spaced Z-nut : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:546652)
    • [UPDATE 19/11/2014] : if you have a PBSME from 2013 do not print this yet. The model has 5mm of extra between the 2 Z bars, that makes it unusable. I'll post the good version soon. [UPDATE 21/11/2014] : you'll find 2 specific files ("simple-2013") dedicated to the Printrbot Simple Maker Edition 2013. This fixes the 5mm difference between the two Z bars. Holes to hold the bearings are squarre (don't worry zip ties still goes there) and a bit tight but that's on purpose in order to get evrything rigid.

Unless I am mistaken, the only difference between this and the original "300mm No Sag" is the alternate mounting of the front end stop switch location.

title: 1-axis hinge/pivot for posable action figures, figurines, etc.

description.text: This object is part of a larger action figure armature.  It is a 1-axis pivot hinge, useful for things like elbows, knees, and in more detailed figures, fingers.

Prints beautifully in PLA at 0.1mm layer height. Recommend a few extra shells for structural integrity, but is remarkably strong at 0.2 density honeycomb infill (I can stand on it without crushing it). You may need to scale this down to 1% of its modeled size. I built this in sketchup, which does better with larger objects later scaled down in, for example, Slic3r or Netfabb. .STL files are oriented to print so that the component axes are aligned for maximum strength after printing. This physible is designed in honor of my beautiful wife. <3

title: Buck Thirty LP Record Stabilizer / Weight #GhostlyVinyl UPDATED 2014-11-23

description.text:
Do you have a jar of spare change in your house? Get rid of 130 pennies by adding them to this record stabilizer. The pennies make the stabilizer the ideal weight to improve your vinyl's sound quality.
.
For the MakerBot Ghostly Vinyl Challenge, I wanted to create something that was useful, original, and easy to print. My first few ideas seemed to be EVERYONE's idea -- 45 adapters, record wall hangers, record organizers, and vinyl brushes -- but then I realized no one had created a record stabilizer. Stabilizers improve sound by dampening unwanted vibrations, level warped vinyl, and cancel bass feedback caused by loud PAs.
.
In order to work properly, record stabilizers need to be heavy. I used 130 pennies (hence the name "Buck Thirty"), or 5 columns of 26 pennies each, to make the stabilizer the ideal weight. The final weight should be around 418 grams or 14.75 ounces. I calculated this by doing research and printing out multiple iterations to get the kinks out.
.
I printed mine in a wood composite PLA material that I then sanded, stained, and varnished, but it would look equally fabulous in Makerbot Khaki filament, or perhaps Neon Orange, Translucent Purple, Jadeite, or Sparkly Dark Blue.
.
This stabilizer was inspired in part by this excellent DIY record stabilizer: http://www.soundfountain.com/amb/puck.html

Print GhostlyRecordWeight and GhostlyRecordWeightTop without support structures. I've printed successfully with 30, 40, and 50 percent infill, but feel free to experiment with different infill percentages to get the right sound.
.
Add 130 pennies, or 5 rows of 26 pennies. Snap on top or glue for a secure fit. For a perfect fit, light sanding may be required.

Let's unite in getting rid of the awful K-cups! Not only are they polluting our earth because they're non-recyclable, but the coffee is also very poor quality. Let's get rid of the unnecessary plastic and use fresh coffee beans!   
I have designed this simple container that stores the perfect amount of coffee grounds for a reusable Keurig basket. Fill up the container on Sunday and you'll have enough grounds for each work day.  
This design cuts down on waste and also keeps your counters clutter free without an obnoxious K-cup holder taking up precious counter space. Once filled, the container can sit neatly next to your Keurig until you're ready for your next brew.

UPDATE: After some initial testing, I updated the body with sloping edges to form more of a spout. This should allow the coffee to pour out easier. I also updated the lid allowing for better flipping up of the star legs.  
This should print easily on all standard printers. I suggest using a flexible material for the lid in order to achieve a snug fit.

comments.text:
It's important to mention that the LID should not be printed at 0.2 layer height or above, because it prints the first layer flat, then it begins to print the triangles on top of that layer. This creates weak hinges that consist of only one layer (which might even have gaps in it that let out coffee freshness). I tried again at 0.165 layer height, and now it prints 2 initial layers before printing the triangles. Much stronger hinges now.
Thanks!

title: Glass Bed Corner brackets for Flashforge Creator Pro

description.text:
These corner pieces are a perfect fit for the FlashForge Creator Pro using the glass build plate by 3DUniverse (http://shop3duniverse.com/products/glass-build-plate). There are two different brackets. Make sure the raised tab is on the short side of the build plate. I purchased some stainless 3mm wingnuts and fender washers to secure the bracket to the build plate. The oversized washer helps prevent the nut from melting into the ABS plastic when it gets hot, which causes the bracket to loosen over time. The wingnuts allow you to tighten the bracket on the fly if they do loosen. .
I'm using this shim to adjust the z-axis: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:440022 Update: I have been printing on this glass bed for about a month now. I was using kapton tape and abs slurry previously, which worked well but I got tired of air bubbles and replacing the tape. For the glass bed I have found that glue stick works really well. I am using the Elmers purple "disappearing" extra wide glue stick. I make two passes with it, first long ways then short. I have found if I get the bed leveled real well, and the right layer of glue stick, I can do 30 prints without having to resurface, which is nice. After a print, I need to let the bed cool down to about 50c before I can remove the part, and then it just pops off. If I try to take it off too soon it is near impossible. Also, I am running the bed at 115c and extruder at 230c. I hope that helps anyone new trying to print onto glass.
I added the shorter .25 inch corners.

title: RepRap Stepper Motor Driver v2.3 Fan Mount

description.text: The RepRap stepper driver (http://reprap.org/bin/view/Main/Stepper_Motor_Driver_2_3) runs fine with most steppers. But if you run it at its highest current (near to the maximum of 2A) the driver chip will get pretty hot. The fan mount will allow you to attach an ordinary 12v CPU fan (34mm hole centres) to the stepper driver board to cool the driver chip. If you want you can use heatsink compound to stick a small SMT-type heatsink to the top of the chip to improve cooling even further.

Print the fan mount upside down in your 3D printer. Attach all the wiring to the stepper driver PCB first. Attach the fan to the mount, then attach that assembly to the PCB. Solder the fan leads in parallel with the 12v supply to the board, taking care to get the polarity right (usually red = +; black = -). The mount has been designed so that you can adjust the stepper-current-controlling potentiometer with a small screwdriver between the fan's blades. Turn it off first...

author: adrian-bowyer

description.text:
This is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4281 . That mount, which I submitted several months ago, would not work with 80/20 aluminum framing. There are 2 differences between that version and this one:
  • Wider body to straddle the T-bolt channel on the 80/20 frame piece.
  • Bearing mounting holes increased to handle M6 sized bolts.
    • This bearing mount was designed to support an 8mm leadscrew (the same one used in the MakerBot CC). A mating 80/20 NEMA17 stepper motor mount ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5391 ) matches the shaft mounting height, 21.5mm, to support the 8mm rod level.

An HBP is suggested for building this 65mm(W) x 40mm(H) x 17mm(D), but I printed the other one fine without it. The room temperature was 30F higher 4 months ago is the only difference I can think of. INFILL DENSITY in the SkeinForge FILL menu was set to 0.2 for my copies but may be set higher depending upon the user's end application. There is not a lot of work to do on these after printing - Scrape out the bearing opening of excess plastic, then press fit the 806 ball bearing in. If you are going to do any sanding, do it before you install the bearing. The fit is tight, but you can carefully add a drop of superglue between the mount and outer rim of the bearing if desired. The 2 block mounting holes might need a small amount to material removed from the holes. After clearing the holes with an X-acto knife, I screwed in the 6mm (1/4") bolts. Sanding with 220A gives the object a better look, but it will work fine without sanding. Use flat washers or cap headed bolts for mounting to increase the surface area holding the block. A small headed bolt would put all kinds of stress on the mounting holes when tightened.

title: Santa Hat - Christmas decoration that fits onto the top of a bottle of Bubbly!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Great Christmas decoration... this Santa Hat has been made to fit on top of a bottle of Bubbly or wine to dress it up during the festive season. Will fit on before opening the bottle and can be used as a cover after opening (...but not as a sealing cap).
The design is shaped internally to make the hat sit slightly back when on an open bottle (i.e. there is an angled internal surface to orient it this way) Can also be used as a simple decorative piece... easy print. Allowing for a 1mm Raft Base change the colours from white to red at 16mm (approx. 39%) and from red back to at white 73mm (approx. 92%) on a Replicator 2. At standard (100%) size the hole in the base will print at approx. 32.5mm in diameter so it is a loose fit onto any wine bottle and is a snug fit onto a bubbly bottle with it's wire and foil still in place. Could easily be resized to suit other bottles etc. (eg. beer bottles). Note: Two additional .stl files (alt_support and no_support) have been added due to different slicing apps/machines capabilities. The alt_support version is required for some slicing apps that have issues with slicing the original .stl file that has thin/fine designed in support. The thicker support alt_support option helps these slicing apps recognise the support but will mean the print takes slightly longer and more filament is used. The no_support .stl has no designed in support. Using automated support with this option is recommended. If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs... and post images of your things in use for others to see!

Use a Raft Base (approx. 1mm) but leave Supports "OFF" as the required support for PLA has been designed in. Print at Standard (0.20mm) resolution with 3 shells and 15% fill.
Allowing for the 1mm Raft Base change the colours from white to red at 16mm (approx. 39%) and from red back to at white 73mm (approx. 92%) on a Replicator 2.
The designed in support should come away easily including the internal support designed inside the cap. Note: A second .stl (alt_support) has been added which has more solid support. This is required for some slicing apps that have issues with slicing the original files fine designed in support. However, the thicker support will mean the print takes slightly longer and more filament is used.

A Tower of Hanoi puzzle, including a 6th disc for a harder difficulty.
How to play;
The objective of the puzzle is to move the entire stack to another rod, obeying the following simple rules:
  • Only one disk can be moved at a time.
  • Each move consists of taking the upper disk from one of the stacks and placing it on top of another stack i.e. a disk can only be moved if it is the uppermost disk on a stack.
  • No disk may be placed on top of a smaller disk.
    More info here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tower_of_Hanoi

Some sanding may be necessary depending on printer accuracy and settings.  Printed and confirmed fitment on my Printrbot Simple Metal using the stock 0.4mm nozzle at 200micron layer height.  The holes are designed 1mm in diameter wider then the pegs.

Inspired by this project by marrr: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:499453 and my recent adventures with OpenSCAD I decided to take a stab at creating parametric lens cup for Oculus Rift DK2. Initially I used marrr's measurements (the ones from one of his pictures) but they turned out to be a little off so I remeasured everything and now it seems to fit correctly ;) and with few modifications to make it printable without support I ended up with a model that looks nice when printed and should fit most users.
Haven't tested it myself (I just managed to print one final version cup after 10 iterations and I need to get some sleep).
The model needs 2 parameters - IPD increase per eye = (your_ipd-63.5)/2 and lens cup height (as mesured from the mount plate to the top lens edge (not the lens center as it's not flat) so it's 20mm for 'A' lens equivalent and 17mm for 'B' lens - or any other value from something around 9mm to infinity if you know the correct height for you eye sight.
As always go to http://www.vr-gear.com/ for the instructions on software modifications.
[EDIT]
Uploaded v2 of the script:
  • improved clip design for better printability for extreme heights
  • less play in lens mount.
  • better instructions in the code
    [EDIT 2]
    Uploaded v3 of the script:
  • added grips for easier installation
  • added embossed lettering to mark the left and right cup
  • REQUIRES recent OpenSCAD Dev Snapshot and the experimental text module to be enabled. If you don't want to mess with beta software please use v2 version of the script.

Nice work dude, and thank you for reference. I felt my measurements and/or my printer were a bit off, as it didn't fit snugly.
Only used my rift about 10min with glasses (it's a pain), then I had to try this out.
Do you notice more blur on the corners of the screen than with glasses, or is just the FOV larger? I also noticed some kind of reflections off the side of the lenses (or the case)... my -5 dioptre is probably a bit too much of a correction.
comments.author: marrr

comments.text: Hi :) I don't use glasses so I can't answer your questions but using shorter cup without glasses can potentially increase the chromatic aberration due to incorrect distortion applied by the software. AFAIK there is no software available right now that would allow you to adjust lens cup height used for calculating the distortion.  I created this cup due to my wide IPD (69.1mm) and included the height adjustment because of your project and because I came with an idea how to do it when thinking about creating the 20mm (A) and 17mm (B) versions of this file.

title: Guardians of the Galaxy / Star Lord Infinity Orb Electromagnet Display Base V2

description.text: This is my second take on the Electromagnet Base after having seen brand-spanking-new screencaps of the Guardians of the Galaxy DVD. I initially thought the 'base' that the orb magnetizes down onto was a solid triangle, but it instead appears to be three prongs pointing inwards.

Print three (3) of the corner piece models, and three (3) of the flaps. Glue the two corner piece assemblies together - they have guide holes so you can put pins into them to make sure you line them up right. Glue the two halves of each flap together facing outward (meaning, the smooth sides go together). The third part of the flap model should snap into place, and can be secured with M2 screws in the two holes modelled - I use 4mm long ones. You will need three lengths of 3mm metal rod - I purchased a bunch off of Amazon for only a couple bucks. Glue the rod into the corner piece, slide the flap hinge over the rod, then cut the rod to the appropriate length and glue the other corner piece on.

A shelf bracket that holds a vertical label.  
The text plate slides into the bracket holder.  This vertical labelling is a modification of TheNewHobbyist's Shelf Talker.  The label plate bracket is a modification of WilliamAAdams' Yazzonic panel clips.  The plate label is designed to be printed in two colours by using the Pause @zpos feature with the Replicator2.

The text plate is printed with the background colour first and then the text colour. This is done by setting your printer to Pause @zpos = 4 mm. When this height is reached the printer will allow you to change the filament. The Pause @zpos option is set after the printer has started to print. Go to the Utilities menu. This option is available on a Replicator2 with firmware version 7.3 or newer.

This is a custom case for a Spark Core WiFi microcontroller mounted on a “perma-proto” breadboard-style PCB by Adafruit and a solid state relay. The microcontroller is connected to a temperature/humidity sensor and the relay controls a humidifier based on the measured humidity. The sensor values are also logged to a Google Docs spreadsheet. The case was modeled in Autodesk Fusion 360.

comments.text: This was printed with Formlabs' clear resin (http://formlabs.com/en/products/materials/standard/) version 2. The photo on the print bed is how it comes out of the printer, the frosted look is how it looks after I clean off the excess resin in an alcohol bath, I use a brush for that.

description.text: 6 Helix wine cork holder with a letter projecting up (and down) from the base. If you look underneath you will notice this can double as a wax stamp. For customizing you will need FreeCAD, a free and open source CAD program available at http://www.freecadweb.org.

My best results were printed at 97% scale, 3 shells, low infill, ABS @ 245C. To customize with your own itinital, check the screen shot - you can use FreeCAD to change the parameter for "Text String" in the area shown, and you will need to put in the path for the font file you wish to use. Depending on the letter you may want to make the text a bit smaller - simply change the size above where you enter the text string. If you need to move it, you'll have to go up the tree one level and click on "Custom Text," switch to the data tab at the bottom, expand Placement, then expand Position, and move the X and Y coordinates slightly to center your new text. To export, select the 'Wine Cork Holder" and "Custom Text" (not the caps one) at the same time and select Export... from the file menu. Then select Mesh Format, and enter your file name. the STL extension is the default for mesh formats.
Replacement part for when the clip on swim goggles breaks. Modeled after Speedo's design, it works well with the 5mm wide silicone strap that is common to most goggles.

This clip was designed in SolidWorks using basic sketch and extrude functions. Dimensions were directly measured from my Speedo Vanquisher goggles. This is a piece that, for me, often breaks before the goggles wear out or straps break. I used 100% infill on the print and designed the clip with additional load bearing geometry to maximize strength. In the photos, the clear clip is a manufacture original, while the red clip is my design.

author: mattcastb

title: Cooling fan bracket for Makerfarm Prusa I3V

description.text: (To customize this design click on the Open In Customizer link here) This bracket is attached to the left side of stock Makerfarm Prusa i3v extruder and it is used to cool the workpiece layers before printing the next one. This improve printing of pieces with small area layer such as the test STL file attached here. To install attach the fan to the bracket with two M3x12 screws attach the bracket to the left side of the extruder with a M3x20 screw, replacing the existing M2x16 (sticking a tape below the extruder to keep the nut in its place makes things easier) and wire the fan to the Ramps D9 (+) and (-1) terminals. You can control the fan from your slicing software (e.g. Slic3r) or from the Marlin's Control menu (note that fan speed is updated only when you click the rotary switch).  I printed with PLA (material support disabled) and didn't notice any heat issues from the extruder.   (note that I didn't have a M3x20 so used a M3x30 with a 10mm spacer, this is why the screw in the pictures is longer than should be). The fan should be oriented such that it blows the air toward the workpiece. Included here is also a OpenSCAD parametric source file so you can tweaked STL files if needed. Note that this fan doesn't replace the main fan that cools the cooling fans above the nozzle, it is intended to cool off the workpiece.

comments.text: As I have an ABL servo on the left side already, I think I can easily enough mirror this to fit on the right side instead. I'm awaiting a new cooling fan for my power supply, but this will be the first print once my printer is running again.
comments.author: AbuMaia

description.text:
This is a case I designed for the LEA 6H GPS that normally comes with a 3DR ArduPilot.  
The case with screws weighs in at only 29 grams.  The boards slips into the bottom case and is then held in place with the lid.  I suggest adding in a foam where the cable leaves the case in order to avoid rubbing.  This also holds the cable firmly in place in case you accidentally pull or tug on it.  
I opted for the round design simply because it gives me a nice surface area for the screws and is aesthetically pleasing.  I removed the material from the lid to lighten up the design a little, but also so I could see the lights on the GPS.  You can mount thin clear plastic to the underneath of the lid if you would prefer the case closed.

I print my case with 3 perimeters, a 5% fill and at 0.3mm height.  If you want to refine the print, reducing layer height to 0.2mm or 0.1mm is no problem.  
I mount my case on a piece of CF rod with a round servo horn glued to the top using only double sided tape.  I have not experienced a failure yet and use this on two of my drones.

description.text: Here is an LED flashlite that you can build several ways.   It has a top, body and a cover for the battery(s).  There are two top files â€“ one for a 5mm LED and one for an 8mm LED.  The body has a hole for a sub-mini slide switch and a fitted opening for a 9V battery snap.  The battery cover stays on by friction.  There are 2 cover files â€“ one for a 9V batt and one for 2-AAs.  You will need: a high quality, hard plastic T-type battery snap with wires, a back-to-back 2 AA battery holder, an LED, a resistor, and a sub-miniature slide switch like (Jameson No. 621325).

• Install the battery snap. The snap will fit very snug so you will have to sand the ends of the snap a little to get it in. Even though it is very tight, I would still super glue it in place.
  • Wire the switch. Keep all wires/leads as short as possible. Position the switch, tape it in place and drop a dab of hot glue on the back of the switch (inside the body).
  • Install the LED. It also fits tight so use a round file to enlarge the hole just a tad. Put it in and super glue.
  • Wire it. Cut the LED leads and solder the resistor, the ground and the hot wire from switch. I usually do it in that order.
  • Push everything together, check for function (shorts) and then glue the top on.
    Notes: My 8mm LEDs have a forward voltage of 3.2-3.4 volts at 25 MA but they still work on 2 AAs, theyâ€™re just not as bright. For a 9V batt and the 8mmâ€™s I use a 200 Ohm resistor. For 9V and a 5mm, use a 470 ohm. For 2-AA batts you can use a 10 Ohm or less for either size LED.

remixed_from.title: Linear Rail Z Axis for Lulzbot AO-10x and mendelmax printers

title: Z Ballscrews and TAZ X Carriage for AO-10x and Mendelmax Printers

description.text:
This project expands on my previous Linear Z Rail for AO-10x project to incorporate a pair of Z Ballscrews, 10mm X rods, and the Taz 4 X Carriage assembly, allowing the AO-10x Series printers to utilize newer toolheads, up to and including the dual extruder. Before starting this, please ensure you have all the prerequisites of the AO-10x Linear Z rail project completed. You will reuse the Z motor mounts, and portions of the top Z railmount assemblies in this project. Those files have been included for convenience, but the instructions assume you have already completed that project.
You will also need several Aelph Objects / Lulzbot files which are not mine. I have linked to those open source files for convenience but I cannot upload them here. Those files may be found at:m http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/TAZ_printers/ with specific links on the instructions page.
Ballscrews are not inexpensive, but this should be the ultimate in precision upgrades for your printer. She may not print a whole basketball, but you’ll be able to print a really detailed softball!
Development thread is here: https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=654&p=6754#p6754

Parts needed:
One Micrometer Head http://ecatalog.mitutoyo.com/Micrometer-Heads-Series-148-Fine-Spindle-Feeding-of-01mmrev-C1548.aspx
300mm SFU1605 ballscrew with BK12 and BF12 pillow blocks (as found on Ebay)
Assorted heat set inserts for M3 and M5 threads (Mcmaster carr)
Assorted M3 and M5 bolts and washers.
Additional printed parts needed:
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/TAZ_printers/
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/TAZ_printers/x_ilder/x_idler_v2.3.stl
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/AO_printers/bearing_holder/bearing_holder_v1.1.b.stl
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/AO_printers/double_bearing_holder/double_bearing_holder-2.0.stl
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/AO_printers/extruder_mount/extruder_mount-1.1.1.stl
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/AO_printers/x_carriage_guide/x_carriage_guide-1.0.stl
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/4.0/production_parts/printed_parts/TAZ_printers/x_carriage/x_carriage_v2.0.STL
This is a very intensive modification. Please only attempt this if you are very experienced in 3d printer frame upgrades and modifications. Everything except the Z endstop will print without support. Add heatset inserts to the ballscrew mounts and X motor and idler pieces as needed, also the X carriage.

author: KorruptKodoku

description.text:
The Prusa i3 frame isn't supported at the top, therefore it may oscillate or vibrate during a print.
So here is a set of brackets that will support the top of the Prusa i3 frame to the Y-Axis threaded rods.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wlJzWys8nuY Added 6mm versions for smaller threaded rod support of 5-6mm.

Print at 0.3mm with 30% infill.
The top bracket mounting holes line up with the existing holes for the z-axis linear rod support. You will need longer M3 screws to accommodate the extra thickness the bolt will have to travel through - 25mm length is good.
For the bottom bracket, you will need to install a longer length of 10mm threaded rod by an extra 200mm. This will allow 100mm extra to extended on either side of the frame that the bottom bracket can fix onto.
Finally you will need 8-10mm threaded rod with length of 350mm to connect the top and bottom brackets together. Tighten with nuts on either side of the brackets.

comments.text: Ironically enough I've basically made the same design on my own, though I complicated it massively by making the top part one piece with the other part in front holding the rods, and I made it hinged instead of a fixed angle: http://imgur.com/a/ZUFGI#0 (excuse the mess, old pictures) Though my design had a problem in that it didn't really help much until I added an additional set of y-corner parts at the ends of the extended rod bolted to the plastic part holding the diagonal brace (without the y corners there to touch the table the rod ends vibrated a bit), and zip-tied the diagonal brace rod to the frame near the top and near the bottom (one zip tie around the rod, one around the frame, one joining them, all very taught), I have theories that it's because 2x nearly parallel structures doesn't add much rigidity but a triangle does, does this design have a similar shortcoming? If not I wonder what differences in my design caused that problem, the hinges are screwed tight so they shouldn't functionally differ from your solid ones when tightened down, the brace rod feels pretty solid in there. If yours work better I'm tempted to print them, my rods should work fine with them, though I'm kinda tempted to ditch the threaded rods and laser cut frame and go t/v-slot 2020 extrusions, openbuilds and their resellers sell a kit of 12x 50cm v slot extrusions for €50~ with 90 degree brackets, t-slot nuts ahd the bolts for them included.
